objdescid.origination:
Robert Blake
delineator. The sketches and lettering on the verso of Object 18 may reflect Robert's attempts to draw subjects that had been set as exercises for him by older brother William, and, in some instances, corrected by one of them. See Object Note on Object 18.

objinfo.objorder: 1-18 Bentley designates these as pages 1-16, A, P. Not included here, among the 18 objects, are the blank verso of Object 17 (Bentley page B) and the blank recto of Object 18 (Bentley page O). We are also not including Bentley pages C-N, all blanks, which are now housed separately from the leaves bearing the manuscript.
objinfo.numberleaves:
10
Each leaf was originally half of a folio (2 conjugate leaves). Two or more leaves may have been removed, at an unknown time prior to 1905, between leaves 8 and 9 (Objects 16-17 as numbered here). The verso of leaf 9 (page B in Bentley) and the recto of what is now leaf 10 (formerly leaf 16, page O in Bentley) are blank. These blank pages are not reproduced here. Before rebinding in 1978, there were 6 blank leaves (Bentley pages C-N) of the same paper that bears the manuscript between what are now leaves 9 and 10 (Objects 17-18 as numbered here). As the sequence of watermarks and countermarks indicates, these blank leaves were once conjugate with the manuscript. The verso of the final leaf (Object 18 as numbered here and page P in Bentley) bears assorted drawings and inscriptions. It is included in Butlin's catalogue (no. 149) as "The Lamb Lying Down with the Lion and Other Drawings, from 'An Island in the Moon' Manuscript."
objinfo.watermark: crown and shield below, with animals, fleur-de-lis, and a harp within the shield. The watermark appears on leaves 2-8, 10 (Objects 3-16, 18 as numbered here). A countermark, consisting of the letters "G R" under a crown, appears on leaves 1 and 9 (Objects 1-2, 17 as numbered here).
objinfo.pennednumbers: none Object 3 is numbered both 1 and 2 upper left and 5 upper right; Object 5 is numbered 3 upper left and 6 upper right. Objects 7, 11, 13, and 15 are numbered 9, 6, 7, and 8 upper left. All these numbers are in pencil. They are probably not written by Blake and thus are not included in our transcriptions.
objinfo.binding:
quarter brown morocco over buckram boards
Each manuscript leaf is mounted in a paper frame. The present binding was created in 1978; formerly bound in red morocco with each leaf attached to a stub. The former binding included a proofsheet of Blake's woodcuts for Robert John Thornton's *Pastorals of Virgil* (1821) and a note from A.H. Palmer referring to their provenance.

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Early history not known. Acquired before 1893 by Charles Fairfax Murray; given by Murray to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1905. A Fitzwilliam Museum collection stamp appears on the verso of the final leaf (Object 18 here).

repository.department: Department of Manuscripts and Printed Books

lg.l: In the Moon, is a certain Island near by a mighty continent, which small
island seems to have some affinity to England, & what is more extraordinary the
people are so much alike & their language so much the same that you would
think you was among your frien ds . in this Island dwells three Philosophers
Suction, the Epicurean, Quid the Cynic, & Sipsop the Pythagorean. I call them

by the names of those sects
tho' thoughthe sects are not ever
mentiond mentionedthere as being
quite out of date however the things still remain, and the vanities are the
same. the three Philosophers sat together thinking of nothing. in comes -
Etruscan Column the Antiquarian & after an abundance of Enquiries to

no purpose sat himself down & described something that nobody
listend listenedto

so they were
employd employedwhen M rs Gimblet came in
the corners of her

seemd seemedI
dont don'tknow how. but very odd as if she hoped you had not
an ill opinion of her. to be sure we are all poor creatures, well she seated

&
listend listened
seemd seemed to listen with great attention while the Antiquarian
seemd seemed
to be talking of virtuous cats. but it was not so. she was thinking of
the shape of her eyes & mouth & he was thinking. of his eternal fame

the three Philosophers at this time were each endeavour
d ingto conceal

situ situation Erdman (page 449) and Phillips (page 28) read "imagination" as "imaginations".

Inflammable Gass, smiling on him. the 3 Philosophers
the Cynic
Various attempts have been made to decipher the illegible deletions in lines 24-25. The deletion in line 24 appears to have been an inserted addition following "Philosophers" in line 25. Bentley reads the deletion as "Quid" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 876); Phillips as "the older" (page 28); Erdman as "Quid" (deleted), replaced by "the Older", mended to "the Elder", deleted in turn (pages 450, 849n).

that ever ___ What d'ye say What dye say said

and Bentley ( *Writings* volume 2, page 878) and Phillips (page 32) read the deletion as "and"; Erdman (page 451) reads it as "Miss". Our reading of "and" is uncertain.

l.note: Phillips reads "Ma" instead of "M. rs Sigtagatist" (32). Bentley reads "Sistagatist" instead of "Sigtagatist" throughout ( *Writings* volume 2), but, as Erdman indicates, "The name 'Sigtagatist' was first written 'Sistagatist' in most places, but mended" (page 849n). In lines 3-7, it is possible that the women's names replace the deleted men's names, but this substitution is uncertain.

lg.l:
Miss Gittipin & M. rs Nannicantipot,
All the three Philosophers &
very
Deleted at the end of the line is a phrase, "All the three Philosophers", followed by words that Bentley finds illegible ( *Writings* volume 2, page 878), Phillips reads as "& very" (page 32), and Erdman as "and the three Philosophers com[in]g" (page 849n). Our reading of these words ("& very") is uncertain.

l.del: Quid the Cynic. Sipsop the Pythagorean Suction the Epicurean
l.note: In the deletion, Erdman reads "& Suction" (page 849n).

In the deletion, Bentley ( *Writings* volume 2, page 878) and Erdman (page 849n) omit the "&". "Gibble Gabble the wife of Inflammable Gass __" may be part of a larger replacement of women's names for the deleted men's names in lines 4-6.

enterd entered the room &Little Scopprell
enterd enteredthe room In the deletion, Phillips omits the "&" after "room" (page 32). "Little Scopprell ... the room" may be part of a larger replacement of women's names for the deleted men's names in lines 4-6.

"*Arse" apparently replaced the deleted "Ass" before both words were deleted and replaced by "ass_" (added in light ink). Erdman, on the basis of the asterisk, restores "Arse", to read the line as "call me *Arse--)" (pages 451, 849n).

I. I think some how
Ill I'llleave it off there was a woman having

her cancer cut & she
shriekd shriekedso. that I was quite sick
Chap 7
Good night said Sipsop, Good night said the other two then There is a redundant stroke in the first "p" of "Sipsop".
they Quid & Suction were left alone. then said Quid I think that
Homer is bombast & Shakespeare is too wild & Milton has no feelings
they might be easily outdone Chatterton never writ those poems, a

parcel of fools going to Bristol _if I was to go
Id I'dfind it out in a

minute. but
Ive I'vefound it out already ___
If I
dont don'tknock them all

up next year in the Exhibition
Ill I'll
bl be
hangd hanged said Suction. hang The deletion ("bl") is not noted by Bentley and Erdman.
Philosophy I would not give a farthing for it do all by your feelings

and never think at all about it,
Im I'm
hangd hanged if I
dont don'tget up

to morrow morning by four o clock & work Sir Joshua __
Before
ten years are at an end said Quid how I will work those poor milk
sop devils. an ignorant pack of wretches
So they went to bed
Chap 8

Steelyard the Lawgiver. sitting at his table taking extracts from
Herveys Hervey'sMeditations

among the tombs &
Youngs Young'sNight thoughts. This is
f
The heavily deleted words at the end of the line are illegible except for "This is" at the beginning and a lowercase "f" midway. Bentley ventures to decipher "This is" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 885); Erdman, more aggressively, ventures "This is unfair and ?I ?think" (page 456).
He is not able to hurt me (said he) more than making me Constable
or taking away the parish business. Hah!

l.del: O what a scene is here what a disguise
l.note: The ink used to delete this line is lighter than the original ink.

l.add: My crop of corn is but a field of tares

lg.l:
Says Jerome happiness is not for us poor crawling reptiles of the earth
The illegible deletion is not noted by Erdman.

Talk of happiness & happiness
its it'sno such thing - every person has as
The last word of the line is "as", though Bentley ( *Writings* volume 2, page 885) and Erdman (page 456) read "a" without comment.
something
Hear then the pride & knowledge of a Sailor
His sprit sail fore sail main sail & his mizen
A poor frail man god wot I know none frailer
I know no greater sinner than John Taylor

If I had only my self to care fo
rI'd soon make Double Elephant
look foolish. & Filligree work I hope shall live to see __
The wreck of matter & the crush of worlds
as Younge says

Obtuse Angle
enterd enteredthe Room, What news M r Steelyard __ I am

Reading Theron & Aspas
io. said he. Obtuse Angle took up the books one

by one I
dont don'tfind it here said he, Oh no said the other it was the
meditations, Obtuse Angle took up the book & read till the other was

quite
tird' tiredout

Then Scopprell & Miss Gittipin, coming in
Sopprell Scopprelltook up a book "Sopprell": i.e., presumably, a slip for "Scopprell".
& read the following passage

An Easy of Hum
an ingUnderstanding by John
Lookye Locke
man
Gent
"Gent" is written over an obscured word ending in "man", deleted by wash. Erdman (page 848) and Phillips (page 43) read the deleted word at the end of the line as "Gentleman".

John Locke said Obtuse Angle, O ay
Lock Lockesaid Scopprell.
about
The word "about" (an uncertain reading) is written over text that cannot be recovered. Bentley makes out " *three words del* " ( *Writings* volume 2, page 886), while Erdman reads "its a book about" (page 456). Phillips renders the phrase as we do here, though he speculates further that the "first reading may have been 'Steelyard then' written in light brown ink, evidently the same ink used to write the first reading 'Gentleman' immediately above. 'Steelyard then' was then deleted with a full nib in a series of flourishes ending in 'about'" (page 83n).
Now here said Miss Gittipin I never saw such company in my life. you
are always talking of your books I like to be where we talk, - you had With this line, Blake shifts to using a lighter ink.
better take a walk. that we may have some pleasure I am sure I never

see any pleasure.
theres there'sDouble Elephants Girls they have their own

way. &
theres there'sMiss Filligreework she goes out in her coaches & her
Bentley reads "coach" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 886) instead of "coaches".
footman & her maids & Stormonts & Balloon hats & a pair of

Gloves every day & the sorrows of
Werter Werther& Robinsons & the
Queen of Frances Puss colour & my Cousin Gibble Gabble says
that I am like nobody else I might as well be in a nunnery

There they go
to inPost chaises & Stages to Vauxhall & Ranelagh
And I hardly know what a coach is. except when I go to

M r Jacko's he knows what riding is
& he will
& his wife is Phillips reads the final word as "ride" but indicates that this reading is "conjectured" (pages 44, 84). Erdman and Bentley see only a three-word deletion: "he does not". Erdman omits the initial ampersand altogether (page 457). Bentley leaves it standing, undeleted ( *Writings* volume 2, page 887).
the most agreeable woman you hardly know she has a tongue in her head
and he is the funniest fellow. & I do believe he'll go in partnership with
his master. & they have black servants lodge at their house I never saw
such a place in my life he says he has Six & twenty rooms in
his house. and I believe it & he is not such a liar as Quid thinks

he is. but he is always envying Poo Poo hold your tongue hold your
Bentley ( *Writings* volume 2, page 887) and Erdman (page 457) both read the last word of the deletion as "Envying".

tongue. said the Lawgiver. this quite
provokd provokedMiss Gittipin to interrupt

her in her
favourite favoritetopic & she proceeded to use every Provoking speech

that ever she could. & he bore it
^ like a Saint than a Lawgiver and
with great Solemnity he addressd the company in these words
They call women the weakest vessel but I think they are the strongest
A girl has always more tongue than a boy I have seen a little brat
no higher than a nettle & she had as much tongue. as a city clark
but a boy would be such a fool not have any thing to say and if any

body
askd askedhim a question he would put his head into a ho
le& hide
it. I am sure I take but little pleasure you have as much pleasure

as I have. there I stand & bear every
fools fool'sinsult. if I had only
myself to care for. I'd wring off their noses

To this Scopprell
answerd answered. I think the
Ladies Ladies'discourses M r Steelyard
are some of them more improving than any book, that is the way
I have got some of my knowledge
Then said Miss Gittipin M r Scopprell do you know the song of Phebe
and Jellicoe_ no Miss said Scopprell __ then she repeated these

verses while Steelyard
walkd walkedabout the room

Phebe drest like
beauties beauty'sQueen
Jellicoe in faint peagreen
Sitting all beneath a grot

Where the little lamb
s do kinstrot
"kins" in "lambkins" is written over "s do" in "lambs do".
Maidens dancing loves a sporting
All the country folks a courting
Susan Johnny Bet & Joe
Lightly tripping on a row
Happy people who can be

In happiness
compard comparedwith ye
The Pilgrim with his crook & hat

Sees your happiness
compleat complete

A charming Song indeed miss said Scopprell That was all for
Bentley reads "that" for "That" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 888).

here they
recievd receiveda summons for a merry making at the Philosophers
house

I say this evening we'
d llall get drunk, I say dash. an Anthem
an Anthem, said Suction

Winking & blinking

dont don'town me a Philosopher

And kiss my Roman Anus

in the street sing something very
pritty pretty& funny about London
For "pritty" Bentley reads "pretty" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 889). In lines 29 and 31, "about London / O no" is legible but deleted "by washing out" (Phillips page 88n).

tty Phillips reads this line as "My", "written in very pale brown ink", above "Nannicantipot" (pages 47, 88n). But it seems rather to be "tty", mirroring the letters just above, in "pritty", and partly erased.
O noabout Matches Then M rs Nannicantipot sung In line 31, "about Matches" could be replacing the deleted "O no" in the same line and/or the deleted "about London" in line 29.
I cry my matches as far as Guild hall
God bless the duke & his aldermen all

l.note: "When" is washed out but clearly legible above "Then", which replaces it.

lg.l:
Then
said sung Scopprell
I ask the Gods no more
no more no more
Then Said suction come M r Lawgiver your song and the Lawgiver

sung
As I
walkd walkedforth one may morning
To see the fields so pleasant & so gay
O there did I spy a young maiden sweet
Among the Violets that smell so sweet
smell so sweet
smell so sweet
Among the Violets that smell so sweet

Hang your Violets
heres here'syour Rum & water sweet
O ay said Erdman reads the deleted "sweet" as "sweeter" (page 459).
Tilly Lally. Joe Bradley & I was going along one day in the Sugar house

Joe Bradley saw for he had but one eye
saw a treacle Jar Erdman reads the deletion as "?one" (page 459).
So he goes of his blind side & dips his hand up to the shoulder in
treacle, here Il lick lick lick said he Ha Ha Ha Ha Ha Erdman reads the deletion as "ll" (page 459); Bentley does not note the deletion.
For he had but one eye Ha Ha Ha Ho then sung Scopprell
And I ask the Gods no more
no more no more
no more no more
Miss Gittipin said he you sing like a harpsichord, let your bounty descend
to our fair ears and favour us with a fine song

then she sung
This frog he would a wooing ride
Kitty alone Kitty alone
This frog he would a wooing ride
Kitty alone & I

This frog Sing co ck I
cary carryKitty alone
An erased "f", clearly visible before "cock", is the most visible remains of what may be "This frog", which was erased and overwritten with "Sing co" in "Sing cock" (Erdman page 849n, Phillips page 90n).
Kitty Alone Kitty alone

Cock I
cary carryKitty alone
Kitty alone & I
Charming truly elegant said Scopprell
And I ask the gods no more

Hang your Serious Songs. said Sip
p sop & he sung as follows The descender of a corrected "p" remains in the middle of "Sipsop".
Fa ra so bo ro
Fa ra bo ra
F S a ba ra ra ba rare roro
Sa ra ra ra bo ro ro ro
Radara
Sarapodo no flo ro

Hang Italian songs
lets let'shave English said Quid sing a Mathematical

Song Obtuse Angle then he sungEnglish Genius for ever here I go
Bentley reads "Sung" for "sung" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 891).
Hail Matrimony made of Love
To thy wide gates how great a drove

On purpose to be
yok'd yokeddo come
W idows & maids & Youths also
That lightly trip on beauty's toe
Or sit on beauty's bum

Hail
fingerfooted lovely Creatures An illegible letter or other mark may be deleted between "Hail" and "fingerfooted". Phillips reads this as an (undeleted) short dash, "Hail - fingerfooted" (page 48). Bentley and Erdman do not note it.
The females of our human Natures
Formed to suckle all Mankind
Tis 'Tis you that come in time of need

Without you we
shoud shouldnever Breed
Or any Comfort find
For if a Damsel's blind or lame
Or nature's hand has crooked her frame
Or if she's deaf or is wall eyed
Yet if her heart is well inclined
Some tender lover she shall find

That pante
d thfor a Bride
The universal Poultice this
To cure whatever is amiss

In damsel or in Widow gay
Bentley reads "widow" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 892).
It makes them smile it makes them skip
Like Birds just cured of the pip
They chirp & hop away

Then come ye Maidens come ye Swains
Bentley reads "maidens" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 892).
Come & be eased of all your pains
In Matrimony's Golden cage __
I None of Go & be hanged said Scopprel how can you have the face

to make game of Matrimony – What you skipping flea
how dare ye?
Bentley reads "matrimony" for "Matrimony" and "how" for "How" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 892).

Miss Gittipin) allways spoils good company in this manner &
its it'sa shame

lg.l:
Then Quid
calld calledupon Obtuse Angle for a Song & he wiping his face

& looking on the corner of the
cieling ceilingSang
To be or not to be
Of great capacity
Like Sir Isaac Newton
Or Locke or Doctor South
Or Sherlock upon death
Id I'd rather be Sutton
For he did build a house
For aged men & youth
With walls of brick & stone

He
furnishd furnishedit within
With whatever he could win
And all his own
He drew out of the Stocks
His money in a box
And sent his servant
To Green the Bricklayer
And to the Carpenter
He was so fervent

The
windows chimneyswere three score
The word "chimneys" is written over "windows" (line 40). In the next line, the letters "wi" in "windows" are written over "chi" (line 41), thus reversing the original order of those words.

The
chi windows many more
The letters "wi" in "windows" is written over "chi" (line 41). In the previous line, "chimneys" is written over "windows" (line 40), thus reversing the original order of those words.
And for convenience
He sinks & gutters made

And all the way he
pavd paved
To hinder pestilence
Was not this a good man
Whose life was but a span
Whose name was Sutton
As Locke or Doctor South
Or Sherlock upon Death
Or Sir Isaac Newton

The Lawgiver was very attentive &
begd beggedto have it sung over again & again
till the company were tired & insisted on the Lawgiver singing a song
himself which he readily complied with

This city & this country &
brought forth many mayors
To sit in state & give forth law s out of their old oak chairs The "s" at the end of "laws" is made unclear by what may be a spot of ink.
With face as brown as any nut with drinking of strong ale

Good English hospitality
o Othen it did not fail,
With scarlet gowns & broad gold lace would make a yeoman sweat

With stockings
rolld rolledabove their knees & shoes as black as j
i et
Erdman maintains that "jet" is " *mended from* git" (page 850n; also Phillips page 92n).

With eating beef & drinking beer
o Othey were stout & hale

Good English hospitality O then it did not fai

Thus sitting at the table wide the Mayor & Aldermen

The hungr y poor
enterd enteredthe hall to eat good beef & ale
Good English hospitality O then it did not fail

Here they gave a shout & the company broke up
Bentley reads "give" for "gave" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 894).

the windfinder. the following affairs
happend happened.

Come Flammable said Gibble Gabble &
lets let'senjoy ourselves bring the
Puppets. Hay Hay. said he. you sho. why ya ya. how can you
be so foolish__Ha Ha Ha she calls the experiments puppets Erdman (page 462) and Phillips (page 52) read "foolish.--".

tubes. & magic pictures

Here ladies & gentlemen said he
Ill I'll
shew show you a louse. cl
Bentley ( *Writings* volume 2, page 894) and Erdman (page 462) omit the period after "louse". Erdman (page 462) and Phillips (page 52) read the deleted word at the end of the line, which begins with a legible "cl" and has been both struck through and erased, as "climing" (that is, climbing).
or a flea or a butterfly or a cock chafer the blade bone of a tittle

back, no no
heres here'sa bottle of wind that I took up in the bog Phillips reads a period after the comma (page 52).
house. o dear o dear the waters got into the sliders. look

here Gibble Gabble__
lendme your handkerchief. Tilly Lally

smeard smearedthe glass worse

than ever, then he
screwd screwedit on then he took the sliders & then
Bentley reads "slides" instead of "sliders" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 894).
he set up the glasses for the Ladies to view the pictures thus

he was
employd employed& quite out of breath
While Tilly Lally & Scopprell were pumping at the air pump
Smack went the glass__ Hang said Tilly Lally Inflammable Erdman reads a period after the dash (page 462).

Gass
turnd turnedshort round & threw down the table & Glasses &
Pictures. & broke the bottles of wind & let out the Pestilence
He saw the Pestilence fly out of the bottle & cried out

while he ran out of the room. he come out come out
Erdman reads the deleted "he" after "room.", less probably, as "Go" (page 462). Bentley reads the deletions that begin at the end of line 1 as "you are" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 895), Erdman as "you / ar" (page 462), Phillips as "gas / --" (page 55). Beyond the descender on the first word, the deletions are illegible and the readings speculative.
we are putrified we are corrupted. our lungs are destroyd

with the Flogiston this will spread a plague all
thro' throughthe
Island he was down stairs the very first on the back of him
came all the others in a heap
So they need not bidding go
Chap 11
Another merry meeting at the house of Steelyard the Lawgiver

After Supper Steelyard & Obtuse Angle. had
pumpd pumpedInflammable

Gass quite dry. they
playd playedat forfeits &
tryd triedevery method to get
good humour. said Miss Gittipin pray M r Obtuse Angle sing us
a song then he sung

Upon a holy thursday their innocent faces clean
This is the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "Holy Thursday" in *Songs of Innocence* , 1789 (Bentley Plate 19). For accounts of the stages of composition, see Erdman page 850n and Phillips pages 18-20. Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (pages 93-94n).
The children walking two & two in grey & blue & green

Grey headed beadles
walkd walkedbefore with wands as white as snow

Till into the high dome of
Pauls Paul'sthey like
thames Thameswaters flow

O what a multitude they
seemd seemed, these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes were there but multitudes of lambs

l.del: And all in order sit waiting the chief chanters commands

l.add: Thousands of little girls & boys raising their innocent hands
l.note: This line was probably written in the break between the original stanzas 2 and 3 as a replacement for the final line of stanza 2 (line 21) after Blake had deleted it.

lg.l:
Then like a mighty wind they raise to
heavn heaventhe voice of song A four-line stanza (lines 23-26) has been deleted. After it was deleted, the second couplet (lines 25-26) was not reused; the first couplet (lines 23-24) was rewritten and used to introduce the revised stanza below (lines 27-30).

Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of
heavn heavenamong
When the whole multitude of innocents their voices raise
Like angels on the throne of heavn raising the voice of praise
Let cherubim & seraphim now raise their voices high This unrhymed line is unique in a poem otherwise written in couplets. Erdman reads "Cherubim & Seraphim" (page 850n).

Then like a mighty wind they raise to
heavn heaventhe voice of song Lines 28-31 make up the revised stanza that replaces the deleted four-line stanza (lines 23-26) and the unrhymed verse that follows (line 27).

Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of
heavn heavenamon
g g A second lowercase "g" is written over the original "g" in "among", perhaps to strengthen it.

Beneath them s
its itthe
revrend reverendmen the guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity lest you drive an angel from your door

After this they all sat silent for a quarter of an hour
& Mrs Sigtagatist
Bentley reads the deletion as "M rs Sistagatist" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 896).

said it puts me in Mind of my grand
mothers mother'ssong
Bentley reads the deletion as "Grand" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 896).

x
The voice
"The voice" is washed out. These lines (35-44) make up the opening two stanzas of the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "Nurse's Song" in Songs of Innocence , 1789 (Bentley Plate 24). The poem continues on the next page of the manuscript. For accounts of the stages of composition, see Erdman page 850n and Phillips pages 94-95n. Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (pages 94-95n).

When
T t he tongues of children are heard on the green The spacing and lettering suggest that the line originally began "The tongues". Blake then inserted "When" before "The" and altered "The" to "the" to read "When the tongues".
And laughing up on the hill
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still

Then come home
^children the sun is
^down
And the dews of night arise

Com
e
c C ome leave off play & let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No No let us play for it is yet day These two stanzas (lines 1-11) complete the draft of "Nurse's Song" that begins on the previous page (14.35-44).

And we cannot go to
sleep
till
its it'sdark Erdman outlines the sequence of revisions thus: Blake originally wrote "cannot go to sleep", emended it to "cannot sleep till its dark", and then restored the original "cannot go to sleep" (page 850n). Phillips describes a similar sequence, but notes that the original "go to" was overwritten by "get to" and "till its dark" was added to the line (to read "and we cannot get to sleep till its dark"). Phillips claims that Blake then restored the original "go to" by a supralinear insertion and deleted "till its dark" (page 95n). See note for line 4 for additional information about Blake's revisions to these lines.

l.del:
The flocks are at play & we
cant can'tgo away
l.note: Phillips gives a plausible account of the revisions in lines 2-4 that hinges on the notion that Blake, "momentarily forgetting the rhyme scheme [abcb] established in the first stanzas on the preceding page", wrote line 4, made some adjustments in lines 2-3, and then recognizing "his mistake ... restored the original reading" of line 3, deleted line 4, and then "went on to write the next two lines" in conformity with the original rhyme scheme (page 95n).

l.add: Besides the Sky the little birds fly

lg.l:
And the meadows are
coverd coveredwith Sheep
Well Well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed

The little ones leaped & shouted &
laughd laughed

And all the hills
ecchoed echoed

Then
Miss Gittipin
Tilly Lally sung Quid
Sung Quid
Erdman reads a lowercase initial "s" in the undeleted "Sung Quid" at the end of the line (page 463).

O father father where are you going
This (lines 13-20) is the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "The Little Boy lost" in Songs of Innocence , 1789 (Bentley Plate 13). Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (page 96).
O do not walk so fast
O speak father speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost
The night it was dark & no father was there
And the child was wet with dew
The mire was deep & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew

Here nobody could sing any longer. till Tilly Lally
pluckd pluckedup a
spirit & he sung.
O I say you Joe
Throw us the ball
Ive I've a good mind to go
And leave you all
I never saw saw such a bowler

To bowl the ball in a
turd tansey The word "turd" is deleted and replaced by "tansey", written in lighter ink.
And to clean it with my handkercher
Without saying a word

That
b Bills Bill's a foolish fe
llow

l.del: He hit me with the bat
l.note: Erdman reads the beginning of the deletion as "To hit me" (page 850n).

l.add: He has given me a black eye

lg.l: He does not know how to handle a bat

Any more than a
cat
Erdman reads "a[ *ny bird the* " (page 850n); Bentley "[ d he *del* ]" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 897); Phillips "a n old he (page 56).

He has
knockd knockeddown the wicket
And broke the stumps
And runs without shoes to save his pumps
Here a laugh began and Miss Gittipin sung Phillips reads "began-" (page 56).

Leave
l Oleave to my sorrows The phrase "leave to" is presumably a slip for "leave me to". "O" is written over "l" (probably the start of "leave", conjectures Erdman, page 850n).

Here
Ill I'llsit & fade away

Till
Im I'mnothing but a spirit
And I lose this form of clay
Then if chance along this forest
Any walk in pathless ways
Thro Through the gloom he'll see my shadow
Hear my voice upon the Breeze
The Lawgiver all the while sat delighted to see them in such a
serious humour M r Scopprell said he you must be acquainted with a
great many songs. O dear sir Ho Ho Ho I am no singer I must
beg of one of these tender hearted ladies to sing for me __ they all
declined & he was forced to sing himself
Theres There's Doctor Clash
And Signior Falalasole
O they sweep in to the cash
Into their purse hole
Fa me la sol La me fa Sol

l.note: Two lines (15-16) have been deleted, leaving them only partly legible. They may read (with Erdman page 850n), "How many Blackamoors / Coud sing with their thick lips". Blake may have originally started line 15 with "If" before changing to "How" (Erdman page 850n). Bentley reads line 15 less confidently: "If( *?* ) we( *?* ) manage( *?* ) Blackamoors" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 898). And there is considerable uncertainty in the reading of the first word of line 16, which may be "Will" (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 898), "Coud" (Erdman page 850n), or "cant" (Phillips page 59).

Musicians should have
A pair of very good ears
And Long fingers & thumbs
And not like clumsy bears
Fa me la sol La me fa sol
Gentlemen Gentlemen
Rap Rap Rap
Fiddle Fiddle Fiddle
Clap Clap Clap
Fa me la sol La me fa sol

Hm said the Lawgiver. funny enough
lets let'shave
handels Handel'swaterpiece
then Sipsop sung
A crowned king.
On a white horse sitting
With his trumpets sounding
And Banners flying
Thro Through the clouds of smoke he makes his way
And the shout of his thousands fills his heart with rejoicing & victory
And the shout of his thousands fills his heart with rejoicing & victory

Victory Victory -
twas 'twasWilliam the prince of Orange

objnote.p: The blank verso of this leaf, designated as page B in Bentley and showing a considerable amount of show-through of the writing on this recto, is not reproduced here. Two or more leaves may have been removed, at an unknown time prior to 1905, between leaves 8 and 9 (Objects 16-17 as numbered here). Refer to the Work Information for more details about the manuscript. A diagonal pencil inscription at the bottom of the page, not in Blake's hand, reads, "a leaf is evidently missing before this one".

lg.l:
them Illuminating the Manuscript _ Ay said she that would
Bentley reads the opening word of the line as "thus" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 899).
be excellent. then said he I would have all the writing Engraved

instead of Printed & at every other
leaf a high
finishd finished Phillips reads the deleted word(s) following "other" as "sheet a" (page 60). Bentley notes only " *word del* " ( *Writings* volume 2, page 899), while Erdman does not note the deletion.
print all in three Volumes folio, & sell them a hundred pounds
a piece, they would Print off two thousand then said she whoever
will not have them will be ignorant fools & will not deserve to live
Dont Don't you think I have something of the Goats. face says he. Very

like a
Goats Goat'sface __she
answerd answered__ I think your face said he is like

that noble bea
t stthe
Tyger Tiger__ Oh I was at M rs Sicknakens & I
Bentley reads "Sicknackers" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 899), Phillips "Sicknakers" (page 60).
was speaking of my abilities but their nasty hearts poor devils
are eat up with envy __ they envy me my abilities & all the Women

envy your abilities my dear they hate people
who are Between "people" and "who" is a stroke — probably a false start — that Phillips reads as a short dash (page 60).

of higher
abilies abilitiesthan their nasty filthy
Souls Selvesbut do you
"abilies": i.e., presumably, a slip for "abilities". Bentley reads "abilies" as "abities" ( *Writings* volume 2, page 899).
outface them & then Strangers will see you have an opinion __ now
I think we should do as much good as we can when we are at

M r Femality's
do
yo yousnap & take me up _ and I will fall into such "yo": i.e., presumably, a slip for "you".

a passion
Ill I'llhollow and stamp & frighten all the People there & show
them what truth is __ at this Instant Obtuse Angle came in Oh I am
glad you are come said quid

objnote.p: At least some of the sketches and lettering on the verso (reproduced here) may conceivably be the product of both William Blake and his youngest brother Robert (1762-87). The awkwardness and redundancy of some of the work, the bare geometry of the head of the large lion(?) in the lower pair of animals in the upper left quadrant of the page, and the heavy overdrawing on some of the other animals are among the features that may possibly reflect Robert's attempts to draw subjects that had been set as exercises for him by older brother William, and, in some instances, corrected by one of them.
The blank recto, designated as page O in Bentley, and showing a considerable amount of show-through from the ink lines on this verso, is not reproduced here.

Blake The "m" has been smudged. The words "William Blake" appear to have been cancelled.

Lam b n n
"Lamb", written in a very small hand, is almost obscured by the first large "n". The second "n" has been lightly smudged. The illegible text at the end of the line appears to be a partial letter—perhaps "c" or "o".

l.note: The illegible text could be the capital letter "L" or simply a squiggle.

Bl a The letters "Bl" (followed by an uncertain letter "a") are written in backwards lettering. They are also smudged.

fr
The text has been smudged, and is written vertically in the lower right quadrant of the page.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page is covered by scattered bits of handwriting and sketches of several animals, a single bit of vegetation, and the profiles of two human faces. Fragments of formal script not obviously connected to the sketches appear to represent practice efforts at making various letters and letter sequences. In addition, the word "Numeration" appears, along with a few whole and partial signatures of William Blake. With one exception, the handwriting is located on the left three quarters of the page. For further information on the text, see the detailed transcriptions and editors' notes. Near the vertical midline of the page are two human faces in left profile, one above the other. A pair of animals recline near the top left corner. The larger animal may be a lion (with mane and tail), the smaller one possibly a young horse or sheep. Below that pair of animals lie a second pair in positions similar to the first — and with similar forms. Thus the larger is perhaps a lion and the smaller a young sheep or horse. The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs seem similar to those in two, possibly three, other sketches on the page: one below and slightly to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. The third possibly related sketch is a left-facing sheep's(?) head in profile. It is located just to the right of the pair of animals in the top left corner, among lines that suggest clouds. There are elements of several horses — their bodies and heads in various positions but all facing left — sketched down the right side and across the bottom of the page. In addition to the six horses' heads and the partial bodies, there are several wavy horizontal lines, some (perhaps all) of which appear to be attempts at outlining aspects of the bodies of horses. In the upper right quadrant of the page, a left-facing horse, its head partly obscured by ink wash, rears on its hind legs. Between the extended front legs may be a small flower or leaf. To the right of the head and neck of the rearing horse are the profiles of a second and third horse's head, both facing left. Beneath the front shoulders of the rearing horse are a fourth and a fifth horse's head, both again in left profile. The fourth, nearest the rearing horse, is an obscure design suggesting the head of a horse with a prominent eye. Just below the fourth horse's head is a fifth. Two dark, curved lines extend to the right. The upper one may suggest the front shoulder, back, and rear end of this (or perhaps another, or perhaps no particular) horse. A lower line appears to extend from the bottom of that horse's neck to the right and down. Left of the vertical centerline of the page, near the bottom, to the left of the human face in profile, is a sixth horse's head. And in the bottom left corner of the page are the headless torso and hindquarters of a horse, facing left.

component.illusobjdesc: A pair of animals recline near the top left corner. The body of the larger animal, possibly a lion (with a mane and tail) with a somewhat human face, faces left, while its head faces forward. Its front legs are spread, its left (and possibly the suggestion of a right) hind leg extended backward. A smaller animal, possibly a young horse or sheep, lies at the larger animal's left side. It faces right while resting its head, facing away from the viewer, upon the larger animal's back. Its front legs are extended; its hind legs are drawn up underneath or beside its body.

Below the first pair of animals at upper left lie a second pair in positions similar to the first. Thus the larger is perhaps a lion and the smaller a young sheep or horse. The larger animal reclines with the smaller lying against or beside it. The body of the larger animal faces left, its sketchy head apparently facing forward, its front legs spread and extended forward, its rear left leg extended slightly backward, with slight indications of its rear right leg emerging alongside the smaller animal's front legs. The larger animal appears to have a very long tail. The smaller animal, lying along or against the larger animal's left side, faces right with its head possibly resting on the larger animal's side. Its front right leg extends forward, apparently bent at the knee; its back legs are drawn up underneath it.

Near the vertical midline of the page are two human faces in left profile. The upper one has curly hair and what may be a prominent cheekbone or perhaps a stroke of an incomplete letter of the alphabet. The lower facial profile is partly obscured by diagonal lines ending in a jagged flourish at the mouth and then up to the right.
Just to the right of the pair of animals in the top left corner are lines that suggest clouds. Near the right edge of the clouds is the head of a sheep or lion in left profile.

The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs of animals sketched on the left half of the page seem similar to those in two other sketches on the page: one is below and a bit to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. Both, drawn in right-facing profiles with their ears back, may be sheep, lions, or (conceivably though not likely) even young horses or pigs.

The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs seem similar to those in two other sketches on the page: one below and a bit to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. Both, drawn in right-facing profiles with their ears back, may be sheep, lions, or (conceivably though not likely) even young horses or pigs.

There are elements of several horses — their bodies and heads in various positions but all facing left — sketched down the right side and across the bottom of the page. In addition to the six heads, there are several wavy horizontal lines, some (perhaps all) of which appear to be attempts at outlining some aspects of the bodies of horses. Some of these wavy lines seem to be aligned with, and thus associated with, the horses' heads, some not. In the top right corner, for example, two gently curved parallel lines extend from just above the head of the rearing horse to the right margin. Other curved lines down this side of the page may represent attempts to outline the bodies of horses.

On the right half of the page, its head partly obscured by ink wash, a left-facing horse rears on its hind legs. Its mane and forelock are visible, its mouth open, and its front legs, bent slightly at the knee, extend forward. Although only the right leg is clearly drawn, there are strong suggestions of left shoulder musculature and hints of hind legs and tail. Additional sketched lines right of the front legs may indicate multiple positions for the legs.

Near the top right corner of the page, to the right of the head and neck of the rearing horse, are the left-facing profiles of two other horses' heads. The uppermost head is held up, nearly horizontal. Its mouth is open and a lock of its mane extends above its eyes; a portion of its neck is visible. The lowermost head, mouth slightly open, is held nearly vertical, with a forelock and partial mane.

Beneath the front shoulders of the rearing horse are a fourth and a fifth horse's heads in left profile. The fourth, nearest the rearing horse, is an obscure design suggesting the head of a horse held at an angle of 45 degrees and with a prominent eye. Just below the fourth horse's head is a fifth, strongly outlined, positioned vertically with a few sketchy tufts of forelock and its mouth slightly open. Two dark, curved lines extend to the right. The upper one may suggest the front shoulder, back, and rear end of this (or perhaps another) horse. A lower line appears to extend from the bottom of the horse's neck to the right and down.

Left of the vertical centerline of the page, near the bottom, to the left of the profiled human face, is a horse's head, facing left, held vertically with a few tufts of forelock, mouth slightly open(?).

In the bottom left corner of the page are the headless torso and hindquarters of a horse, facing left. Only the upper portion of its rear left leg, extending backward, is visible, along with part of its tail.

Fragments of formal script not obviously connected to the sketches appear to represent practice efforts at making letters and letter sequences. In addition, the word "Numeration" appears, along with a few whole and partial signatures of William Blake. With one exception, the handwriting is located on the left three quarters of the page. For further information on the text, see the detailed transcription and editors' notes.
Just between the front legs of the rearing horse is a small design, possibly a flower or leaf of some sort.
